{{Infobox military person |name= Flora D. Darpino |birth_date= |death_date= |birth_place= |death_place |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= |image=Flora Darpino.jpg |image_size=220px |caption = Lieutenant General Darpino |nickname= |allegiance= {{flag|United States}} |branch=[[File:United States Department of the Army Seal.svg|20px]] [[United States Army]] |serviceyears= 1987 – present |rank=[[File:US-O9 insignia.svg|35px]] [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]] |commands= [[The Judge Advocate General's Legal Center and School]]
United States Army Legal Services Agency |unit= |battles= [[War on Terror]]
[[Iraq War]] |awards= [[File:US Defense Superior Service Medal ribbon.svg|30px]] [[Defense Superior Service Medal]]
[[File:Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|30px]] [[Legion of Merit]] (3)
[[File:Bronze Star ribbon.svg|30px]] [[Bronze Star Medal]] |laterwork= }} '''Flora D. Darpino''' (born 1961) is an American general and military lawyer who is the 39th [[Judge Advocate General of the United States Army]]. She is the first woman to hold that position, which she assumed on September 4, 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.army.mil/article/110602/Army_swears_in_first_woman_as_Judge_Advocate_General/ |title=Army swears in first woman as Judge Advocate General |date=September 4, 2013 |first=J.D. |last=Leipold |publisher=United States Army |accessdate=October 6, 2013}} ==Biography== Darpino graduated with a B.A. from [[Gettysburg College]] in Pennsylvania, and received her [[Juris doctor|J.D.]] from [[Rutgers School of Law–Camden]] in [[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]], [[New Jersey]], in 1986.{{cite web |url=https://www.jagcnet.army.mil/LCSCommander |title=Brigadier General Flora D. Darpino, Commander and Commandant |publisher=United States Army |accessdate=August 8, 2013}} She later received an [[LL.M.]] in military law from [[The Judge Advocate General’s School]]. She is a member of the [[New Jersey State Bar Association|New Jersey]] and [[Pennsylvania Bar Association|Pennsylvania Bars]].{{cite web |url=http://rci.rutgers.edu/~rualumni/awards/hda.php?show=205 |title=Hall of Distinguished Alumni: Flora D. Darpino |publisher=[[Rutgers University]] |accessdate=October 6, 2013}} ==Career== Darpino received a direct commission into the United States Army Judge Advocate General’s Corps in January 1987. Her first assignment was to [[VII Corps (United States)|VII Corps]] in Stuttgart, Germany, where she was a trial defense counsel and chief of the civil law division. She was later the training officer and assistant operations officer for the U.S. Army Trial Defense Service; litigation attorney, litigation division, U.S. Army Legal Services Agency; chief, Administrative Law, [[101st Airborne Division (Air Assault)]] at Fort Campbell, Kentucky; assistant executive officer, Office of The Judge Advocate General; chief, Judge Advocate Recruiting Office; staff judge advocate, [[4th Infantry Division (United States)|4th Infantry Division]] at Fort Hood, Texas and Tikrit, Iraq; deputy staff judge advocate, [[III Corps (United States)|III Corps]] at Fort Hood; chief, Criminal Law Division, OTJAG; staff judge advocate, [[V Corps (United States)|V Corps]], in Heidelberg, Germany; and staff judge advocate, [[United States Forces – Iraq]], in Baghdad, Iraq. She served as the commander of the United States Army Legal Services Agency, Fort Belvoir, Virginia, and as the commander of the Judge Advocate General's Legal Center and School. ==Awards and decorations== {| |[[File:AirAssault.svg|100px]] |[[Air Assault Badge]] |- |[[File:United States Army Staff Identification Badge.png|80px]] |[[Army Staff Identification Badge]] |- |[[File:4_Infantry_Division_SSI.svg|80px]] |[[4th Infantry Division (United States)|4th Infantry Division]] [[Combat Service Identification Badge]] |- |[[File:JAGcrest.gif|50px]] |[[Judge Advocate General's Corps, United States Army]] [[Distinctive Unit Insignia]] |- |[[File:ArmyOSB.jpg|50px]] |2 [[Overseas Service Bar]]s |} {| |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=US Defense Superior Service Medal ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Defense Superior Service Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=2|type=oak|ribbon=Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Legion of Merit]] with two bronze [[oak leaf cluster]]s |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Bronze Star ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Bronze Star Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=5|type=oak|ribbon=Meritorious Service ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] with silver oak leaf cluster |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Army Commendation Medal ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Commendation Medal#Army|Army Commendation Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Army Achievement Medal ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Army Achievement Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Joint_Meritorious_Unit_Award_ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Joint Meritorious Unit Award]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Army Superior Unit Award ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Superior Unit Award]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=1|type=service-star|ribbon=National Defense Service Medal ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[National Defense Service Medal]] with one bronze [[service star]] |- |{{Ribbon devices|number=3|type=service-star|ribbon=Iraq Campaign ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Iraq Campaign Medal]] with three service stars |- |{{ribbon Ribbon#Army|Army Overseas Service Ribbon]] with bronze [[award numeral]] 3 |} She is married with two daughters.{{cite web |url=http://magazine.rutgers.edu/features/spring-2012/5-star-alumni |title=5
